list.title: Question 1
list.content:
The ocean pressure, $P$, under sea level can be modelled by the function
$$$P(D)=10D​+1$$$
where $D$ is the distance in metres below sea
level and $P$ is measured in atmospheres.
A submarine cruising near the surface is submerged according to the
function
$$$D(t)=10+5t$$$
where $t$ is measured in minutes and $D$ is
the distance the submarine is below sea level, measured in
metres.


Find the composite function $P∘D$ and explain what it means in
the
context of this question[3]



Find and interpret $(P∘D)(10)$.[2]
list.markScheme:
The composite function can be expressed as
$$$(P∘D)(t)​=P(D(t))=P(10+5t)=1010+5t​+1=2+2t​​(1)​$$$
This composite function represents the ocean pressure (in atmospheres) outside the submarine at time t minutes.


Substituting $t=10$ in (1), we get
$$$(P∘D)(10)​=2+210​=7​​$$$
This result means that after 10 minutes, the ocean pressure outside the submarine is 7 atmospheres.

list.title: Question 2
list.content:
The temperature, $T$, measured in degrees Celsius, above ground level in
Bagan, Myanmar, can be modelled by the function
$$$T(H)=37−160H​$$$
where $H$ is the height above ground,
measured in metres.
The height, $H$, of a hot air balloon carrying tourists on a particular
day in Bagan is given by the function
$$$H(t)=40+10t$$$
where $H$ is in
metres, and $t$ is the time in minutes after reaching cruising
height.


Find the composite function $T∘H$ and explain what it means in
the
context of this question.[3]



Find $(T∘H)(36)$ and explain what it means in the context of
this
question.[2]
list.markScheme:
The composite function can be expressed as
$$$(T∘H)(t)​=T(H(t))=T(40+10t)=37−16040+10t​=37−16040​−16010t​=36.75−16t​​(1)​$$$
This composite function represents the temperature outside the hot air balloon after $t$ minutes of the balloon cruising.


Substituting $t=36$ in (1), we get
$$$(T∘H)(36)​=36.75−1636​=34.5​​$$$
It means that after 36 minutes of the hot air balloon cruising, the temperature outside the balloon is 34.5 degrees Celcius.

list.title: Question 3
list.content:
The subscription fee for an online project management software by
AB-Tech is $$40$ per month. If the customer buys for a whole year in
advance, a discount of $$130$ is applied.
This can be modelled by the following function, $P(n)$, which gives the
total cost when paying annually for the subscription.
$$$P(n)=40n−130,n≥12$$$
where $n$ is the number months.


Find the total cost of buying a subscription for $2$ years.
[2]



Find $P−1(1790)$. [2]



The subscription price for a different online project management tool by
YZ-tech is $$35$ per month, however customers can only purchase
annually in advance, and there are no discounts. The total subscription
cost of YZ-tech's software is less than AB-tech's software when $n>k$ .

Find the minimum value of $k$. [3]
list.markScheme:
Substituting $n=24$ into the $P(n)$ function, we get
$$$P(n)P(24)​=40n−130=40(24)−130=$830​​$$$


Let's denote $P(n)$ by $y$. To find the inverse we can interchange
the variables $n$ and $y$ and rearrange for $y$, as follows
$$$yn40yyP−1(n)​=40n−130=40y−130=n+130=40n+130​=40n+130​​$$$
We can now find
$P−1(1790)$ as follows
$$$P−1(1790)​=401790+130​P−1(1790)=48 months​​$$$


For AB-tech's software we we were given the pricing function
$$$P(n)=40n−130$$$
For YZ-tech, we can define the function, $S(n)$, to
represent the subscription price for their software
$$$S(n)=35n$$$


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2b908e8c-786e-4fec-844c-19b9653ea308/images/7386b1f2-6825-49b7-88df-da2a1e5501e7/7402d7e1fc9d51e4e9f6b0f5ea74f75143d1438e.svg)


From the graph, $S(n)<P(n)$ for $n>26$.
The price of YZ-tech's software is less than AB-tech's when $n>26$.
Therefore,  $k=26​$

list.title: Question 4
list.content:
A tyre manufacturing company has found that the number of tyres it
produces, $N$, can be modelled by the function
$$$N(t)=3t−9$$$
where $t$
is the number of hours the factory operates per day, with a minimum of 3
hours.
The profit the company makes, $P$, in dollars, depends on the number of
tyres produced, and is modelled by the function
$$$P(N)=60N−850$$$
where
$N$ is the number of tyres produced.


Find the company's profit or loss if it operates for $6$ hours per
day.[2]



Find the company's profit in terms of the hours of operation per
day, $t$.[2]



Determine the number of hours the company needs to operate the
factory per day in order to earn a positive profit. Give your answer
to the nearest hour.[2]
list.markScheme:
Substituting $t=6$ in $N(t)$, we get
$$$N(6)Thus, the profit is given by P(9)P(9)​=3(6)−9=9=60(9)−850=−310​$$$
Therefore, operating $6$
hours a day, the company has a loss:
$$-310​$


The profit in terms of the hours of operation per day can be found
by the composite function $P∘N$. Hence, we get
$$$(P∘N)(t)​=P(N(t))=P(3t−9)=60(3t−9)−850(P∘N)(t)=180t−1390​(1)​$$$


The company has a positive profit if (1) is greater than 0. Hence
$$$(P∘N)(t)180t−1390tt​>0>0>1801390​>7.72.​$$$
Therefore, the
factory needs to operate
$8​$
hours per day in order for the company to earn a positive profit.

list.title: Question 5
list.content:
The number of fish in a lake, $f$, is given by the function
$$$f(x)​=450e−0.1x+50​$$$
Where $x$ is the approximate concentration of algae in the lake, measured in parts per billion (ppb) and $x≥0$.


Determine the range of $f$. [2]



Find an expression for $f−1(x)$. [3]



The lake is considered "healthy" if there are at least $430$ fish at any given time.

Calculate the range of algae concentrations for which the lake can be considered healthy. [3]
list.markScheme:
A sketch of $f(x)$ on the G.D.C. shows that the function has a $y$-intercept at $500$, and is a decreasing function.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/a63d7358-95e5-47b5-8fd1-6ae2a911d1ab/images/970c948b-055a-4278-93f2-46aa7699c0c7/1207.JPEG)


We can also see that as $x→∞$, $f(x)→50$ (but it never reaches $50$). Therefore the range of $f$ is
$$$​50<f≤500​​A2​$$$


To find the inverse function, we will first re-write our function using $y$ to represent $f(x)$, this will make manipulation of the function easier. We have
$$$y​=450e−0.1x+50[Where y=f(x)]​$$$
We now switch $x$ and $y$, thereby creating the inverse function.
$$$x​=450e−0.1y+50[Where y=f−1(x)]​(M1)​$$$
Now we can rearrange to make $y$ the subject. This will be our inverse function.
$$$x−50450x−50​ln(450x−50​)−10ln(450x−50​)​=450e−0.1y=e−0.1y=−0.1y=y​(M1)​$$$
We can now substitute $y=f−1(x)$ for our final answer.
$$$​f−1(x)=−10ln(450x−50​)​​A1​$$$


We found in part (a) that the maximum number of fish in the lake is $500$, and this occurs when the concentration of algae is 0 ppb.
$$$​(A1)​$$$
For the lake to be considered healthy, the minimum number of fish is $430$, and this will coincide with the maximum allowable algae concentration.
That is, the maximum algae concentration is $a$, such that $f(a)=430$.
Using the relationship between a function and its inverse, we could therefore say $f−1(430)=a$.
Substituting the value $430$ into our inverse function from part (b), we have
$$$f−1(430)​=−10ln(450430−50​)=1.6907...=1.69(3 s.f.)​(M1)​$$$
Hence the range of algae concentrations for which the lake can be considered healthy, in parts per billion, is
$$$​0≤x≤1.69​​A1​$$$

list.title: Question 6
list.content:
The circumference, $C$, of a given circle can be represented by the
function
$$$C(A)​=2ππA​​,A≥0,​$$$
where $A$ is the area of the circle.
The graph of the function $C$, for $0≤A≤24$, is shown below.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/0b7df521-ef1b-4c8a-87b1-32e564791325/images/ce866e5f-cd7d-44ed-9b43-19469f4d4737/3388e210bb4d6f02426816cb2651396f2822c4c1.svg)




Find the value of $C(24)$. [1]



On the grid above, draw the graph of the inverse function, $C−1$.
[3]



In the context of the question, explain the meaning of
$C−1(2π)=π$. [1]
list.markScheme:
Evaluating $C(A)$ for $A=24$, we get
$$$C(A)​=2ππ24​​≈17.4​​$$$


If we draw the graph of the inverse function, $C−1$, on the grid
below, we have


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/0b7df521-ef1b-4c8a-87b1-32e564791325/images/3b17f6c6-ed96-4a9a-b40e-195870b66409/fae26733051cc1a7c15c3478abb0d0697e69d7fa.svg)




$For a given circle, when the circumference is 2π, the area is π​$

list.title: Question 7
list.content:
A town is planning to construct a jogging path in a grass field
$170$ m long and $70$ m
wide. The path is to be the shape of a rectangle with two semicircles of
radius $x$, as shown in the diagram. The sides of the rectangle
connecting the circles are to be $100$ m long.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3b56cb39-04a1-4c8f-b16c-f5a5245daaaa/images/d44b0d34-7ffb-4949-8d1e-a3dbe9c818bb/22448faee8b9c6574b3fdefa8505f67030a94583.svg)




Write down a function, $P$, (in metres) for the perimeter of the
jogging path, in terms of the radius, $x$.[1]



Determine the domain and range of $P$, taking into consideration the
dimensions of the grass field.[2]



Find an equation for the inverse function $P−1(x)$. Express your
answer in the form $P−1(x)=mx+c$.[2]



The designers of the path are deciding whether the total length of the
path should be $300$ m,
$400$ m, or $500$ m. The
designers want to maximise the perimeter of the path, but fit the path
in the grass field.

Determine which length is most suitable, given the
dimensions of the grass field.[2]
list.markScheme:
The perimeter for the path is the sum of the two straight sides
connecting the circles and the perimeter of a complete circle of
radius $x$. We get
$$$P(x)=200+2πx​$$$


The length of the path will be $100+2x$ and its width $2x$.
Therefore we require $100+2x≤170$ and $2x≤70$. Hence
$$$Domain: 0≤x≤35.​​$$$
For
the range, the function $P(x)$ is increasing and $P(0)=200$ and
$P(35)=200+70π$. We get
$$$Range: 200≤P(x)≤200+70π.​​$$$


Let's denote $P(x)$ by $y$. To find the inverse we can interchange
the variables $x$ and $y$ and rearrange for $y$, as follows
$$$yxy​=200+2πx=200+2πy=2πx−200​P−1(x)=2π1​x−π100​​​$$$


For each of the proposed perimeters $P$, we can find the radius
value $x$ as $x=P−1(P)$, then the length and width of the running
track can be calculated, as shown in the following table.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3b56cb39-04a1-4c8f-b16c-f5a5245daaaa/images/a51374e0-38d2-4194-a69c-09dd7705203d/8985560368df68be350c8eca5afbe5b19a733963.svg)


From the table, we can see that the largest perimeter of the options
that still fit inside the grass field dimensions is
$$$P=400m.​$$$

list.title: Question 8
list.content:
Harry is planning on constructing a glass window in one of the outer
walls of his house. The dimensions of the wall space available are 2m x
2m. Harry wants the window to be in the shape shown in the diagram
below. The bottom section is a rectangle and the top part is a
semicircle of radius $x$ m. Harry wants the
height of the rectangle to be fixed at 1 m.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3b6eacbd-eff9-4731-9da7-653273efcc3e/images/2857a1b4-2a9c-44c8-8215-923593110245/4b81f49038bd3a70fed3ed55e752da67f426bdf2.svg)




Write down a function $P$ (in metres) for the perimeter of the
window in terms of the radius, $x$.[1]



Determine the domain and range of $P$, taking into consideration the
dimensions of the available wall.[2]



Find an equation for the inverse function $P−1(x)$. Express your
answer in the form $P−1(x)=mx+c$.[2]



Harry wants to maximise the size of the window, however the window frame
that covers the perimeter of the window can only be 5, 6, or 7 metres
long, due to manufacturing restrictions.

Determine which perimeter length is the best option for
Harry.[2]
list.markScheme:
The perimeter for the window is the sum of the three sides of the
rectangle and the semicircle, thus we get
$$$P(x)​=Rectangle width+2×Rectangle height+Semicircle=2x+2(1)+2​2​πx​P(x)=2+(2+π)x​​$$$


The width of the window will be $2x$ and the height $1+x$.
Therefore, we require $2x≤2$ and $1+x≤2$.
Hence
$$$Domain: 0≤x≤1.​​$$$
Now
for the range, the function $P(x)$ is increasing and $P(0)=2$ and
$P(1)=4+π$. Therefore,
$$$Range: 2≤P(x)≤4+π.​​$$$


Let's denote $P(x)$ by $y$. To find the inverse we can interchange
the variables $x$ and $y$ and rearrange for $y$, as follows
$$$yxy​=2+(2+π)x=2+(2+π)y=(2+π)x−2​P−1(x)=(2+π)x−2​​​$$$


For each of the proposed perimeters $P$, we can find the radius
value $x$ as $x=P−1(P)$, then the length and width of the window
can be calculated, as shown in the following table


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3b6eacbd-eff9-4731-9da7-653273efcc3e/images/d54f8441-1a6b-4d76-8a64-a7b4d6867247/95900dceeb57876cf3bec3ce67dc138811471933.svg)


From the table, we can see that the perimeter that maximizes the
dimension of the window that fits in the wall is
$$$P=7m.​$$$

list.title: Question 9
list.content:
The radius of a cylindrical container with height
$x$ cm is
$$$r(x)=x56​,4≤x≤16​$$$

Find the range of $r$.[3]


The function $r−1$ is the inverse function of
$r$.




Find $r−1(8)$.


Interpret the answer to part (b) (i) in
context.


Find the range of $r−1$.[4]
list.markScheme:
A sketch of $r(x)$ shows that the minimum value is found where $x=16$ and the maximum value is found where $x=4$.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/47ec87ad-d03d-40ae-b070-86ca7d589f8a/images/5e3319c6-2a5b-4f5e-9751-0736b3e580f0/AI1002a.PNG)


Evaluating $r$ at the endpoints of its domain, we get
$$$r(4)r(16)​=456​=14=1656​=3.5​$$$
Therefore the range of $r$ is $3.5≤r≤14​$




Let $r−1(8)=a$. This implies that $r(a)=8$.
$$$a56​aa​=8=856​=7​$$$
$r(7)=8$ and therefore $r−1(8)=7​$


When the radius of the container is $8$cm the height is $7$cm


Using the definition of a function inverse, we have
$$$range of r−1​=domain of r​$$$
Therefore the range of $r−1$ is $4≤r−1≤16​$

list.title: Question 10
list.content:
A conical funnel is used to add water to a scientific experiment. The
funnel initially contains 3 L
of water, and the water flows out of the funnel at a rate of
40 mL per minute.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/56f5072c-2f53-49d8-b6ea-7999bc16ba97/images/ed36937a-80cb-4a49-9a96-eaeafce08153/8c377cf98298a7a684cfd677cfc233747ca8bc06.svg)




Determine a function for the volume $V$ (in millilitres) of water
remaining in the funnel after $t$ minutes.[2]



If there is $V$ mL of water in the funnel, show that the height of
the water can be expressed as
$h(V)=33πV​​$ cm.
[4]



Find the composite function $h∘V$, and interpret what it means
in the context of this question.[3]



Find $(h∘V)(15)$ and explain what it means in the context of
this question.[2]
list.markScheme:
The volume of water starts at 3000 mL and decreases 40 mL per
minute. Hence, we get
$$$V(t)=3000−40t​$$$


Let's consider a cross-sectional view of the right part of the
funnel, as shown in the figure


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/56f5072c-2f53-49d8-b6ea-7999bc16ba97/images/8916d387-34e1-40df-8464-c10b8811efef/1fa1545b27c671db53373226d01df2aa7fd58824.svg)


From the diagram, using similarity, we get
$$$10r​r​=30h​=3h​​$$$
Using the volume formula for a cone, we get
$$$VVh3​=31​π(3h​)2h=271​πh3=27πV​h=33πV​​​​$$$


The composite function can be expressed as
$$$(h∘V)(t)​=h(3000−40t)=33π3000−40t​​​(1)​$$$
This composite function represents the height of water remaining in the funnel after $t$ minutes.


Evaluating $t=15$ in (1), we get
$$$(h∘V))(15)​=33π3000−40(15)​​≈27.4cm​[by using G.D.C.]​$$$
$$$It means that after 15 minutes the height of water remaining in the funnel is 27.4 cm.​$$$

list.title: Question 11
list.content:
Consider the following composite shape, consisting of a rectangle of
length 50 cm and varying width
$x$ cm, and three-quarter circle with its center
at a vertex of the rectangle and radius equal to the rectangle width,
$x$ cm.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6067168f-a8d6-43d6-af12-c8d85c12a9bc/images/4f9c52d8-322c-471b-bd07-d4575afde2e5/9ed23f8a95d65fb8498a74d7b3a0d8921a8b6a79.svg)



Determine a function, $L$, in terms of $x$, for the total length of
line seen in the diagram. This consists of both the perimeter of the
rectangle and circumference of the three-quarter circle.[2]


Constraints are placed on the dimensions of the composite shape. The
total length and width of the composite shape cannot exceed
$100$ cm and $80$ cm
respectively.


Determine the domain and range of $L$, taking into
consideration these constraints.[2]



Find an equation for the inverse function $L−1(x)$.
Express your answer in the form $L−1(x)=mx+c$.[2]



Suppose $L$ can only be in multiples of $100$ cm
(i.e., $100$ cm,
$200$ cm, $300$ cm,
...).

Determine the maximum length of $L$ that satisfies the
constraints.[2]
list.markScheme:
The total length of the line, $L$, is the sum of the rectangle
perimeter and $3/4$'s of the circumference of a circle of radius
$x$. We get
$$$L(x)​=2(50)+2x+43​(2πx)=100+2x+23πx​L(x)=100+(2+23π​)x​​$$$


Since the total length cannot exceed
$100$ cm, we get $50+x≤100$. Similarly,
the total width cannot exceed $80$ cm,
therefore $2x≤80$. Hence
$$$Domain: 0<x≤40.​​$$$
The
function $L(x)$ is increasing, $L(0)=100$, and $L(40)=180+60π$.
Hence
$$$Range: 100<L(x)≤180+60π.​​$$$


Let's denote $L(x)$ by $y$. To find the inverse we can interchange
the variables $x$ and $y$ and rearrange for $y$, as follows
$$$yxy​=100+(2+23π​)x=100+(2+23π​)y=4+3π2(x−100)​L−1(x)=4+3π2x​−4+3π200​​​$$$


For each of the possible values of $L$, we can find the radius value
$x$ since $x=L−1(L)$. The length and width of the composite shape
can then be calculated and compared against the constraints, as
shown in the following table.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6067168f-a8d6-43d6-af12-c8d85c12a9bc/images/0fb0cecd-64f1-4b3c-8840-8c94b4968b3a/881fb34d4c0132d6f520788601f45a7a6a476a82.svg)


From the table, we can see that the largest line length of the
options that satisfies the constraints is
$$$L=300cm.​$$$

list.title: Question 12
list.content:
The perimeter, $P$, of a given rectangle can be represented by the
function
$$$P(A)​=62A​​,A≥0,​$$$
where $A$ is the area of the rectangle.
The graph of the function $P$, for $0≤A≤24$, is shown below.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/ab39cb62-6642-463f-8d55-b3b4e61d9fc1/images/d77d8ca4-60bf-47df-b71e-f5b1a82ac6ef/13be64c3a363091e834dcc3848fda5575c4c9b07.svg)




Find the value of $P(24)$. [1]



On the grid above, draw the graph of the inverse function, $P−1$.
[3]



In the context of the question, explain the meaning of
$P−1(12)=8$. [1]
list.markScheme:
Evaluating $P(A)$ for $A=24$, we get
$$$P(A)​=6224​​≈20.8​​$$$


If we draw the graph of the inverse function, $P−1$, on the grid
below, we have


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/ab39cb62-6642-463f-8d55-b3b4e61d9fc1/images/ff3fed55-9366-4196-a9da-e2951114048a/0d0a8ad4bbd75e6a6d48466c8f25e5a869af08fe.svg)




$For a given rectangle, when the perimeter is 12, the area is 8​$

list.title: Question 13
list.content:
The area, $A$, of a given square can be represented by the function
$$$A(P)​=16P2​,P≥0,​$$$
where
$P$ is the perimeter of the square.
The graph of the function $A$, for $0≤P≤20$, is shown below.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d67d010e-f96a-4959-94d7-dd830ba69f41/images/db5dae3b-4d37-46d8-a488-586d1cdc2312/8c2c1a298c1b79e92e64f94fe2b4a4d452e488ad.svg)




Find the value of $A(20)$. [1]



On the grid above, draw the graph of the inverse function, $A−1$.
[3]



In the context of the question, explain the meaning of
$A−1(4)=8$. [1]
list.markScheme:
Evaluating $A(P)$ for $P=20$, we get
$$$A(P)​=16202​=25​​$$$


If we draw the graph of the inverse function, $A−1$, on the grid
below, we have


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d67d010e-f96a-4959-94d7-dd830ba69f41/images/8288a0de-f259-43ef-a694-da2f13679dc3/508588bd8662a40575516587374d1e3379be6249.svg)




$For a given square, when the area is 4, the perimeter is 8​$

list.title: Question 14
list.content:
James goes on a cross-country bike ride which comprises of
8 km of flat terrain followed by
12 km of constant uphill sloping terrain. We
know James can cycle at a speed of 24 km/hr in
flat terrain, however we don't know his speed on sloping uphill terrain,
and therefore denote this by $x$ km/hr.


Show his average speed over the entire ride, in terms of $x$, can be
expressed as[2]

$$$S(x)=x+3660x​​$$$


Find $S−1(x)$.[2]



Hence find the speed he needs cycle over the sloping uphill terrain
in order to obtain an average speed of
20 km/hr for the whole ride.[2]
list.markScheme:
Let's denote by $A$ the flat path of 8 km
and by $B$ the sloping path of 12 km as in
the figure.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/361c2286-0171-4365-8d5c-3bedad288df0/images/81a36013-06f0-46e1-8aa4-b19078f485f7/51afddbd3335432582ce0a7448d0ba409510d7ad.svg)


First, we find the time it takes James to cycle the path $A$. From
the speed formula in terms of distance and time, we have
$$$tA​Similarly, the time required to cycle B istB​Finally, we can find the average speed in terms of x as followsS(x)​=VA​dA​​=248​=31​=VB​dB​​=x12​=tA​+tB​dA​+dB​​=31​+x12​20​=3xx+36​20​S(x)=x+3660x​​(1)​$$$


We can find the inverse of S(x) by using expression (1), changing
$S(x)$ to $y$, interchanging $x$ and $y$, and then rearranging for
$y$. We get
$$$yxxy+36x60y−xyyHence, the inverse function is​=x+3660x​=y+3660y​=60y=36x=60−x36x​S−1(x)=60−x36x​​​$$$


The speed for the uphill sloping terrain required to obtain an
average speed of 20 km/hr for the whole ride
can be found by $S−1(20)$. We get
$$$S−1(20)=60−2036(20)​=18.$$$
Therefore, James needs
to cycle at a speed of
$18km/hr​$
over the uphill sloping terrain.

list.title: Question 15
list.content:
A cable making machine in a factory produces 5 metres of cable every 3
minutes. After 4 hours of continuous use, the machine requires 48
minutes of preventative maintenance. Apart from this preventative
maintenance, the machine works continuously without interruption.

Determine the function, $L$, that represents the length of cable
produced in terms of time, $t$, measured in days.[2]


The company sells the cable it produces and has found that the income
(in dollars) from selling $L$ metres of cable can be modelled by the
function
$$$I(L)=(3−7​)L−500​$$$

Determine a function for income, $I$, in terms of time,
$t$, in days. [3]


The company is considering an investment in a new machine that produces
6 metres of cable every 3 minutes and needs 60 minutes of preventive
maintenance for every 7 hours of use.


Show that the income function for this new machine, in
terms of the number of days, $t$, can be expressed as.[3]

$$$I2​(t)=(3−7​)(2520t)−500​$$$


Determine a function, $D$, to model the difference in
incomes between the two machines, in terms of the number of days,
$t$.[3]



The company decides to purchase the new machine only if it can recover
the cost of the machine through the difference in incomes over six month
period (assume 180 days).

Find the highest amount the company will be willing to pay
for the new machine, rounded to the nearest dollar.[2]
list.markScheme:
A complete cycle operation-maintenance of the machine takes 4 hours
and 48 minutes, and thus, in one day, there are 5 complete
operation-maintenance cycles.
Therefore the amount of cable produced in $t$ days can be expressed
as
$$$L(t)​=Amount produced by 5 operation-maintenance cycles×tdays=(3min5m​)(1hr60min​)(1cycle​4hr​)(1day​5cycles​​)tdays​L(t)=2000t​​$$$


We can find an expression for the composite function $I∘L$ as
follows
$$$I∘L(t)​=I(L(t))=I(2000t)I∘L(t)=(3−7​)(2000)t−500​(1)​$$$


This machine can complete 3 operation-maintenance cycles per day,
and so the amount of cable it produces is
$$$L2​(t)​=Amount produced by 3 operation-maintenance cycles×tdays=(3min6m​)(1hr60min​)(1cycle​7hr​)(1day​3cycles​​)tdays​L2​(t)=2520t​​$$$
Now we find the composite $I∘L2​$:
$$$(I∘L2​)(t)​=I(L2​(t))=I(2520t)(I∘L2​)(t)=(3−7​)(2520)t−500​(2)​$$$


The difference in incomes between the two machines is the difference
(2)$−$(1). We get
$$$D(t)​=[(3−7​)(2520)t−500]−[(3−7​)(2000)t−500]=(3−7​)(2520−2000)tD(t)=(3−7​)(520)t​(3)​$$$


Substituting $t=180$ in (3), we get
$$$D(180)=(3−7​)(520)(180)≈33157.68$$$
The company is willing to pay
$$33158​$
for the new machine.

list.title: Question 16
list.content:
A function is defined by $g(x)=3−x+312​$ for $−9≤x≤9$,
$x=−3$


Find the range of $g$. [3]



Find the value of $g−1(0)$. [2]
list.markScheme:
The graph of $g(x)=3−x+312​$ is plotted below.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/616164a4-faa5-4676-9f3c-4769c3d41be8/images/23cbcbe8-15fc-47be-83cd-0d50dcfbc06b/AI881a.PNG)


From the graph, the range of $g$ is $(−∞,2]∪[5,∞)]​$


$g−1(0)$ corresponds to the value of $x$ when $g(x)=0$.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/616164a4-faa5-4676-9f3c-4769c3d41be8/images/47112aa7-51a3-49b0-9ae0-889a5f78ea51/AI881b.PNG)


From the graph, $g(x)=0$ when $x=1$. Hence,
$$$g−1(0)=1​​$$$

list.title: Question 17
list.content:
A function is defined by $f(x)=x2−4x+1​​$, for the
domain $−1≤x≤5$, $x=2$


Find the range of $f$. [4]



Find the value of $f−1(52​)$. [2]
list.markScheme:
The graph of $f(x)=x2−4x+1​​$ is plotted below


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/771c20b0-6647-4ac7-8e39-ad9d8d9a73fc/images/a00f5f74-aa09-49c4-9f67-0d0f12c451c2/AI883a.PNG)


From the graph, the range of $f$ is
$$$​(−∞,0]∪[0.117,∞)])​​$$$


$f−1(52​)$ corresponds to the value of $x$ when $f(x)=52​$.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/771c20b0-6647-4ac7-8e39-ad9d8d9a73fc/images/45b4d1cb-3fb1-439c-ad5f-8bba89649cdf/AI883b.PNG)


From the graph, $f(x)=52​$ when $x=3$. Hence,
$$$​f−1(52​)=3​​$$$

list.title: Question 18
list.content:
A function is defined by $f(x)=x+5​$, $x≥−5$


Determine the domain and range of $f$. [3]



Find the value of $f−1(6​)$. [2]
list.markScheme:
The graph of $f(x)=x+5​$ is plotted below.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/8ae200fc-c8c2-45b4-aa13-f0e9f279cb9a/images/881074fb-10d0-4145-9bf1-ee5c090fa571/1805e337e073512237286acb5583906bdf31bb84.svg)


From the graph, the domain of $f$ is
$$$[−5,∞)​$$$
and the range of $f$ is
$$$[0,∞)​$$$


$f−1(6​)$ corresponds to the value of $x$ when
$f(x)=6​$.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/8ae200fc-c8c2-45b4-aa13-f0e9f279cb9a/images/5e47c30a-f23c-47d5-b947-709f7668078d/7c19742e74bbe79b3eeb3b8509335ac2df5057a0.svg)


From the graph, $f(x)=6​$ when $x=1$. Hence,
$$$f−1(6​)=1​$$$

list.title: Question 19
list.content:
The function $f$ is defined by $f(x)=x−27x−24​$,
for $−3≤x≤12$,
$x=2$.


Find the range of $f$. [3]



Find an expression for the inverse function $f−1(x)$. [3]



Write down the range of $f−1$. [1]
list.markScheme:
If we draw the graph of $f$, by using G.D.C., we
have


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/8f054f1a-9ea4-4053-a5d1-6fa515e9906d/images/1a167d6a-7e1e-416a-b9c6-b49067e30e6a/6790d3e3a83e5ec16eb602a4d64032370f792ab9.svg)


Hence, using the $y$-coordinates of A and B, we find
$(−∞,6]∪[9,∞)​$


If we solve the equation $x=(f∘f−1)(x)$ for
$y=f−1(x)$, we find
$$$xxxx(y−2)xy−2xxy−7yy(x−7)y​=f(f−1(x))=f(y)=y−27y−24​=7y−24=7y−24=2x−24=2x−24=x−72x−24​f−1(x)=x−72x−24​​​$$$


The range of $f−1(x)$ is equal to the domain of $f(x)$, therefore
the
range of $f−1(x)$ is
$−3≤f−1(x)≤12 , f−1(x)=2​$

list.title: Question 20
list.content:
Emily is training for a triathlon and cycles at a speed of
20 km/hr for 15 minutes followed by $t$ hours
running at a speed of 15 km/hr.


Show that a function to model her average speed $S(t)$ is given by
[2]

$$$S(t)=1+4t20+60t​.​$$$


Find $S−1(t)$.[2]



Hence find the time, $t$, if the average speed Emily travels at is
16 km/hr.[2]
list.markScheme:
Let's denote the path she cycles at 20 km/hr
by $A$, and the running path at 15 km/hr by
$B$.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/8f827a7c-24a2-40b1-90d9-68752b6dd2e8/images/d63f160d-16e2-4fbf-8d6f-d331f12f3279/18f8e72209382b1575d513cf1f3df1aca73bd68e.svg)


The distance Emily travels during the cycle ($A$) in km can be found by
$$$dA​​=VA​tA​=(20)(41​)=5​$$$
Similarly, the distance Emily travels during the run ($B$) can be expressed as
$$$dB​​=VB​tB​=15t​$$$
Hence, we can find the average speed in terms of $t$ as follows
$$$S(t)​=tA​+tB​dA​+dB​​=41​+t5+15t​=41+4t​5+15t​S(t)=1+4t20+60t​​(1)​$$$


We can find the inverse of S(t) by using expression (1), changing
$S(t)$ to $y$, interchanging $t$ and $y$, and then rearranging for
$y$. We get
$$$yt20+60y(60−4t)yyHence, the inverse function is​=1+4t20+60t​=1+4y20+60y​=t+4ty=t−20=60−4tt−20​S−1(t)=60−4tt−20​​​$$$


The time $t$ she has to run to get an average speed of
16 km/hr is $S−1(16)$. Hence, we get
$$$S−1(16)=60−4(16)16−20​=1.​$$$
